answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Since September, our city has had three Leafs (Leaves?). They are used mostly by Public Works staff to shuttle between a handful of destinations in the ten-square mile city and the surrounding county, for instance from the yards to city hall to the water plant and back. They work very well for this, and they only need to be charged about once a week, which takes about four hours with 240-volt chargers, an added cost at two sites. The Leaf is cheaper to operate than a regular car. 
We bought the Leafs with a federal grant, and they supplement our varied fleet, which includes hybrid Civics and Priuses, CNG-adapted pickups, and diesel hybrid transit buses. We'll learn more about lifetime cost of ownership and the right mix of vehicles for the fleet. Right now the Leafs look ideal for crosstown shuttling  between offices and to community events. Below are two links, to our fleet page and to a local news article on the Leafs which quotes Public Works staff and a supplier of rapid chargers. 
http://www.charlottesville.org/Index.aspx?page=565 
http://www.cvilletomorrow.org/news/article/13051-city_electric-vehicles/

answers.author: Maxwell Moline
answers.text:
Daniel,
The Knowledge Network has a couple of resources specifically about the Nissan Leaf, and more about using energy-efficient vehicles in general.
This article from PM magazine discusses electric cars and has a focus on the Leaf:
http://webapps.icma.org/pm/9301/public/pmplus2.cfm?author=Maury%20Blackman&title=Electric%20Cars:%20How%20Local%20Governments%20Can%20Jump-Start%20Preparations%20for%20the%20Next%20Wave%20in%20Transportation&subtitle=
And this report talks about new electric car stops that are being built for the Leaf. 
http://icma.org/en/Article/100115/First_elect
In 2010, there was a Knowledge Network survey about the use of alternative fuel vehicles.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302034/Alternative_Fuels_Survey_Spreadsheet
For more information and examples of the use of alternative fuel vehicles, you can browse the Knowledge Network’s Alternative Fleet Vehicles topic page.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/topic/9/alternative_fleet_vehicles
Let us know if we can be of further help.
Max Moline
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA

author: Daniel Ortiz-Hernandez
text:
Hello, 
I'm trying to find out if any local government uses or intends to purchase a Nissan Leaf vehicle for their fleet? Like to get you thoughts on its practical use, battery life, distance you are able to travel. Or if you have other electric vehicles, what was your criteria for selecting it?
Thanks.
